title: Cranioplastic Surgery and Acclimation Training for Awake Mouse fMRI
procedures: Cranioplastic surgerySurgeryAnesthetize mice with isoflurane (1.5% with air).Remove head skin and exposed the cranium.Carefully polish the surface of the cranium with a small gauze pad containing physiological saline.Place super-bond (Super-Bond C & B) on the skull.Mount cranioplastic acrylic cement (GC UNIFAST Trad) on the superbond with a male plastic Luer Fitting (Figure 1).Mice could recover for more than a week after surgery. Carefully check animal body weight and behavior every day.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/e3972/bioprotoc-11-07-3972-g001.jpgFigure 1. Cranioplastic surgery. A thin layer of super-bond was placed on the skull. The Luer fitting was then rapidly fixed with cranioplastic acrylic cement.Acclimation trainingMouse handling during recoveryContinue handling during the recovery for at least 1 week. The handler lift the mice with cupped hands and hold the animal for around 30 s (Figure 2).We confirme that mice did not urinate and did not jump from the cupped hands during handling.Once body weight increased compared to pre-surgery weight, traine the mice to acclimatize to the awake fMRI conditions before fMRI experiments.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/e3972/bioprotoc-11-07-3972-g002.jpgFigure 2. Handling with cupped hands. Photo shows the handling of a representative mouse with implantation of the Luer fitting to the skull.Acclimation trainingTrain mice for 4 days to acclimatize to the awake fMRI conditions before fMRI experiments.  Train them at the same time each day (10:00-18:00) to minimize the effects of circadian rhythm variations.During the first 2 days, use a pseudo-MRI system consisting of a non-magnet bore and a head positioner (Figure 3 and Figure 4). The acrylic bar is tightly fitted with an elastic tube. Then  train the mice in the MRI bore for the next 2 days.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/e3972/bioprotoc-11-07-3972-g003.jpgFigure 3. Fixation of the head with the custom-made head positioner. Photo of the fixed head (left) and schematic figure of the head fixation system. The head fixation system was custom made.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/e3972/bioprotoc-11-07-3972-g004.jpgFigure 4.

Acclimation training with pseudo-MRI head positioner Anesthetize mice in anesthesia chamber using 2% isoflurane with air.Once mice are anesthetize, stop isoflurane and rapidly and tightly fixed their head with the non-MRI head fixation system (Figure 3).The earplug is cut down to fit to the mouse ears and put into the mouse ear canal using tweezers (Figure 5D). The size of dedicated earplugs should be bigger than ear canal so as not to make a gap with the ear canal.Gently wrap the body with paper towel or gauze so that the mice can move their limbs within the paper towel (or gauze) cover (Figure 4).In general mice awoke within 10 min following cessation of isoflurane delivery. This was confirmed using electroencephalography (Tsurugizawa et al., 2020b).Mice remain in the pseudo-MRI apparatus for 30 min on the first day and 90 min on the second day.Monitor the respiratory rate and heart rate during the training. A small pneumatic pillow, by which respiration is measured, is attached under the animal’s abdomen with surgical tape. The electrodes for electrocardiogram (ECG) are inserted under the skin.Awake fMRIFollowing 2 days training outside of the magnet, start acclimation training in the magnetic bore.Anesthetize mice in anesthesia chamber with 2% isoflurane with air.Continue isoflurane anesthesia via the mask (1.5% with air) during the setup.Fix the animal’s head in the dedicated volume coil with head positioner and the animal’s body is positioned on the bed (Figure 5A). Use the same head positioner as Figure 3. The size of dedicated earplugs should be bigger than ear canal so as not to make a gap with the ear canal.Insert dedicated earplug (cut down to a 5 mm length) into the mouse ear canal (Figure 5D).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/e3972/bioprotoc-11-07-3972-g005.jpgFigure 5. Dedicated volume coil, head fixation system, and eay plugs. A. Dedicated mouse volume coil and bed.

B. Schematic figure of the fixation of mouse head. C. Diagram of the volume coil and bed. D. Left: Earplug for human and (D center) dedicated earplug for mouse. D. Right: The ear of mouse with dedicated earplug. The picture and schematic figure are from Tsurugizawa et al. (2020b).Gently wrap the body with paper towel or gauze so that they can move their limbs within the paper towel (or gauze) cover.Adjust basic frequency, magnetic field homogeneity, reference pulse gain and receiver gain. This adjustment is automatically performed by Bruker system.Acquire an anatomical image with rapid acquisition with relaxation enhancement (RARE) sequence following cessation of isoflurane using the following parameters: time of repetition, 2,500 ms; effective echo time, 60 ms; RARE factor, 8; acquisition matrix, 128 × 128; field of view, 16 mm × 16 mm; slice thickness, 1 mm; 15 slices and four averages.Start to acquire fMRI data 10 min after cessation of anesthesia using the following parameters: time of repetition, 2,000 ms; echo time, 21 ms; acquisition matrix, 80 × 80; field of view, 16 mm × 16 mm; slice thickness, 1 mm; 15 slices and four averages.Monitor the respiratory rate and heart rate during the MRI experiment (Model  1025  , SA Instrument).Perform fMRI training (3rd and 4th days) with the same protocol as the fMRI experiment.Complet the acclimation training when the heart rate and respiratory rate are reduced to nominal levels (Figure 6). If they do not decrease, we continued acclimation training.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/e3972/bioprotoc-11-07-3972-g006.jpgFigure 6. Heart rate and respiratory rate during acclimation training. (A) Heart rate and (B) respiratory rate reduced to nominal levels at the end of the training (n = 15). *P < 0.05 by Tukey-Kramer multiple comparison test. Data are from Tsurugizawa et al. (2020b).
